extraction_metadata.article_title: Economic and business perspectives on smartphones as multi-sided platforms

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Multi-sided platform - A platform that connects two or more distinct types of customers and is characterized by the existence of indirect externalities where an extra customer on one side generates benefits for customers on the other side
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms that serve a variety of "customers," including consumers (users), handset makers, network operators, app developers, advertisers, and chip manufacturers.' | Page 2: 'These are platforms that connect two or more distinct types of customers and that are characterized by the existence of indirect externalities — an extra customer on one side generates benefits for customers on the other side.'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms' | Page 2: 'We refer to the operating systems that are at the core of our study as "mobile operating systems," "smartphone operating systems," or simply "operating systems."' | Page 3: 'As multi-sided platforms, mobile operating systems have faced the chicken-and-egg problem'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We apply the multi-sided platform model to understand the evolution of the smartphone industry.' | Page 2: 'In this study we apply the multi-sided platform model to understand the evolution of the smartphone industry.'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the target customer type of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Even though by their very nature mobile operating systems connect a variety of customers, their ultimate goal is to attract consumers (users).' | Page 2: 'We focus on the strategies that mobile platforms have resorted to in order to achieve this objective.'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the typical size of offering companies that adopt this software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Apple, which sold the iPhone as an integrated and proprietary bundle of hardware and software' | Page 3: 'Google acquired it in July 2005 for an estimated $50 million' | Page 2: 'Research in Motion (RIM) as an electronics and computer-science consulting business'

extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'In late 2011 consumers purchasing a smartphone in the U.S. ranked the mobile operating system itself as the second most important reason' | Page 6: 'In Europe, they ranked the operating system third after network quality' | Page 5: 'In Europe, the European Commission mandated a single standard for second-generation mobile telecommunications services'

extracted_data.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'the BlackBerry, a device that allowed business executives to access their corporate email wirelessly from anywhere at any time' | Page 6: 'In late 2011 consumers purchasing a smartphone in the U.S.' | Page 6: 'smartphone owners have increasingly tended to use smartphone features'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of product or service offered by the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms' | Page 7: 'Third-party apps are at the essence of smartphones' | Page 7: 'In late 2011, the selection of apps available for a smartphone platform was ranked the third most important factor'

extracted_data.question_text: How is the software delivered or deployed in the business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms' | Page 3: 'Smartphones were no longer single-purpose or multi-purpose devices, but rather universal handheld computers that incorporated a telephone'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the intellectual property regime adopted by the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'The first model is one in which the mobile operating system is closed-source, and its owner is a corporation that functions also as the handset maker. This is the approach adopted by RIM for BlackBerry OS, Palm, and Apple for iOS.' | Page 4: 'The fourth model — adopted by Google for Android — is one in which the mobile operating system is open-source and is licensed to handset makers for free.'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there specific restrictions or compatibilities of licensing mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'Google chose to follow a strategy not unlike the one that Microsoft had employed in the 1980s in its relationships with PC makers — Google developed an operating system and licensed it to any and all handset makers. The key difference between Google's Android and Microsoft's DOS and Windows was that Android was open-source and cost the handset manufacturers nothing.'

extracted_data.question_text: What are the revenue sources of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 9: 'Attracting advertisers has been important for mobile platform owners or sponsors for two reasons. First, ads placed on the platform have been a significant source of revenues and profits, considerably more so for Google than for Apple.' | Page 3: 'The company would generate revenues by selling support services for the system.' | Page 8: 'All app stores have had the same objective — supplying apps that make the relevant mobile operating system more desirable to consumers'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the base unit for pricing of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 9: 'advertisers seek eyeballs. In recent years advertisers have tended to migrate following the eyeballs' migration paths' | Page 7: 'A similar survey conducted in 2012 asked developers about the main factors driving platform choice. The top five criteria identified by developers for adoption of a platform were that the platform have a large installed base of devices'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the price presentation structure of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'Google developed an operating system and licensed it to any and all handset makers. The key difference between Google's Android and Microsoft's DOS and Windows was that Android was open-source and cost the handset manufacturers nothing.' | Page 3: 'Apple and Cingular — which was acquired by AT&T in December 2006 — held protracted negotiations that led to a business deal centered on the introduction of an Apple phone'

extracted_data.question_text: What currency and billing periodicity are used in the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'the proportion of mobile phone owners in the U.S. — smartphone, feature phone, and multimedia phone owners combined — who used their mobile phones to send or receive email increased from 19 percent to 38 percent between December 2007 and May 2011' | Page 9: 'Mobile advertising revenues reached $3.18 billion in the U.S. in 2012'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the role of the offering company in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms that serve a variety of "customers," including consumers (users), handset makers, network operators, app developers, advertisers, and chip manufacturers.' | Page 2: 'Multi-sided platforms have three fundamental features... Third, an intermediary is required to internalize the externalities flowing from one side of the platform to the other.'

extracted_data.question_text: What type of network effect is present in the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'Second, in multi-sided platforms there are indirect externalities arising from the interconnection among different customers types... a developer that starts creating apps for a mobile operating system makes users of the operating system better off, and an additional user of a mobile operating system makes developers engaged in creating apps for it better off.'

extracted_data.question_text: What are the customer acquisition channels of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'Apple launched the App Store, which featured applications for both the iPhone and the iPod touch' | Page 4: 'Google chose to follow a strategy not unlike the one that Microsoft had employed in the 1980s in its relationships with PC makers — Google developed an operating system and licensed it to any and all handset makers'

extracted_data.question_text: Does the software business model presented in the article use cloud marketplaces or platforms?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'Apple launched the App Store, which featured applications for both the iPhone and the iPod touch' | Page 7: 'Google's own app store, Android Market, was announced in August 2008' | Page 7: 'BlackBerry launched its app store in April 2009, Nokia in May 2009, Samsung in September 2009, and Microsoft in October 2010.'

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Superior features and capabilities
Customer Segment: Consumers, developers, handset makers, network operators
Channels: App stores, handset makers, network operators
Revenue Streams: Advertising, app store fees, support services
Key Resources: Operating system, installed base, developer ecosystem
Key Activities: Innovation in hardware and software, platform management
Key Partnerships: Handset makers, network operators, developers
Cost Structure: Development costs, marketing, platform maintenance
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'We identify five different business models that have developed historically in the mobile-operating-system market.' | Page 3: 'Apple and RIM achieved success by marketing an integrated bundle of hardware and software' | Page 7: 'At its core, an application store is an auxiliary two-sided platform vis-à-vis the core platform'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Consumers/Users | End users | Use platform services | Interact with developers through apps | Handset Manufacturers | Device makers | License OS | Compete with each other | Network Operators | Service providers | Provide connectivity | Compete for users | App Developers | Content creators | Develop apps for platform | Compete for user attention | Advertisers | Revenue generators | Place ads on platform | Compete for user attention | Chip Makers | Hardware suppliers | Supply components | Work with handset makers
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms that serve a variety of "customers," including consumers (users), handset makers, network operators, app developers, advertisers, and chip manufacturers.' | Page 2: 'First, there are a variety of customers, including users, handset makers (such as Samsung and Nokia), network operators (such as AT&T, T-Mobile, and Verizon), advertisers, chip makers, and application developers'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 9: 'Attracting advertisers has been important for mobile platform owners or sponsors for two reasons. First, ads placed on the platform have been a significant source of revenues and profits' | Page 1: 'Even though by their very nature mobile operating systems connect a variety of customers, their ultimate goal is to attract consumers (users).' | Page 3: 'Google was reportedly concerned about two facts: first, web surfing had started to migrate from personal computers to mobile phones, and second, the Internet capabilities of existing smartphones were limited'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'The top five criteria identified by developers for adoption of a platform were that the platform have a large installed base of devices (chosen by 54 percent of respondents), that it facilitate app development at low cost (43 percent)' | Page 3: 'The key to BlackBerry's success was supplying one feature — seamless access to corporate email — that drew large numbers of users' | Page 4: 'The key difference between Google's Android and Microsoft's DOS and Windows was that Android was open-source and cost the handset manufacturers nothing.'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'Multi-sided platforms have three fundamental features... First, for multi-sided platforms to emerge at least two distinct types of customers have to exist.' | Page 3: 'As multi-sided platforms, mobile operating systems have faced the chicken-and-egg problem' | Page 6: 'In late 2011 consumers purchasing a smartphone ranked the quality of the network of the mobile service provider as the top factor they considered in the purchase process'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Exclusive carrier agreements → Limited market reach
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'Apple's iPhone worked on one network only, AT&T, for a number of years after launch. Google, on the other hand, attempted to make the Android operating system available on as many handsets and networks as possible as early as possible.' | Page 6: 'the fact that the iPhone was exclusively associated with a network that was viewed as a laggard may have slowed down its progress in the early years'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'A key characteristic of every multi-sided platform is that at the starting point it faces a chicken-and-egg problem: in a platform with two customer types (say, Type-I and Type-II), Type-I customers do not want to commit to participating in the platform until they see enough commitment on the part of Type-II customers' | Page 3: 'Google, which entered an already crowded market, chose to attract consumers indirectly by first attracting handset manufacturers and network operators'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Open source strategy → Reduced development costs → Faster adoption
Free licensing → Handset maker attraction → Market penetration
App store creation → Developer attraction → User engagement
Multi-carrier partnerships → Network coverage → User satisfaction
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'Google developed an operating system and licensed it to any and all handset makers. The key difference between Google's Android and Microsoft's DOS and Windows was that Android was open-source and cost the handset manufacturers nothing.' | Page 7: 'Apple launched the App Store, which featured applications for both the iPhone and the iPod touch' | Page 3: 'Google chose to attract consumers indirectly by first attracting handset manufacturers and network operators'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Market Share; 72.40%; Percentage; Q3-2012; Gartner Research; Gartner press releases | App Downloads; 35 billion; Units; September 2012; App Store; Apple | App Downloads; 25 billion; Units; September 2012; Google Play; Google | Developer Usage; 76%; Percentage; 2012; VisionMobile Survey; VisionMobile | Mobile Advertising Revenue; $3.18 billion; USD; 2012; Gartner Research; Gartner
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'By Q1-2011 Android had become the leading operating system in the world market with a 35.99 percent share of all units sold' | Page 8: 'By September 2012 about 700,000 apps were available on Apple's App Store and users had made roughly 35 billion app downloads. But Google Play was catching up — it had 675,000 apps available and 25 billion app downloads' | Page 9: 'Mobile advertising revenues reached $3.18 billion in the U.S. in 2012'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the temporal period and maturity of the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We study how different mobile operating-system owners or sponsors have managed to innovate in these various dimensions, often by engaging other customer types. In the concluding section we rely on the insights derived from multi-sided platform theory to analyze the reasons why two mobile platforms — Apple's and Google's — have been able to displace various incumbents.' | Page 3: 'The smartphone market changed radically with the arrival of Apple's iPhone in June 2007'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of evidence presented in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'After reconstructing the history of smartphones, we explore the variety of business models that operating system owners or sponsors have implemented' | Page 2: 'Our study goes beyond the Holzer and Ondrus (2011) analysis in a number of ways. For one, we provide empirical evidence on mobile app developers' | Page 2: 'our study attempts to provide a systematic empirical examination of the evolution of the smartphone industry within the framework of multi-sided platform theory'

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?
extracted_value: Google Android → Open source platform strategy
Research in Motion (RIM) BlackBerry → Enterprise email focus
Microsoft Windows Mobile → Licensed platform model
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms' | Page 3: 'The smartphone market changed radically with the arrival of Apple's iPhone in June 2007' | Page 3: 'In September 2008 T-Mobile released the first smartphone running on Android, the operating system developed by Google' | Page 3: 'RIM's first smartphone, the BlackBerry 5810, reached the market in 2002'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Integrated model → Owner is also handset maker (Apple, RIM)
Licensed model → Closed-source OS licensed to handset makers (Microsoft)
Consortium model → Joint venture of handset makers (Symbian)
Open source model → Free OS with alliance partners (Google)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'We identify five different business models that have developed historically in the mobile-operating-system market. The first model is one in which the mobile operating system is closed-source, and its owner is a corporation that functions also as the handset maker. This is the approach adopted by RIM for BlackBerry OS, Palm, and Apple for iOS.' | Page 4: 'The second model — adopted by Microsoft for Windows Mobile — is one in which the mobile operating system is closed-source, and its owner is a corporation that licenses it to handset makers for a price.'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Continued competition between Apple and Google
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 9: 'Mobile advertising revenues reached $3.18 billion in the U.S. in 2012 ($9.76 billion worldwide) and were forecast to reach $3.8 billion in the U.S. ($11.4 billion worldwide) in 2013' | Page 10: 'Multi-sided platform theory provides useful insights to understand the economic and business history of smartphones. We have interpreted mobile operating systems as forming the core of mobile platforms that serve the needs of a variety of customers.'
